body:
why does this pull is not succeed？

Some checks were not successful
1 errored and 1 successful checks
Details Required  continuous-integration/travis-ci/pr — The Travis CI build could not complete due to an error
and i don't see anything in mxnet/master, i should create a folder like /zh?
yes, create mxnet/doc/zh
use mx.model.FeedForward(epoch_size=xxx)

Just to confirm, so if I define epoch size to be smaller than the number of examples I have in the entire training recorditerator, then the iterator rolls over at the start of the next epoch , and it only resets when all batches in the iterator have been processed, regardless of the end of an epoch? Thanks for the prompt response.

Just to confirm, so if I define epoch size to be smaller than the number of examples I have in the entire training recorditerator, then the iterator rolls over at the start of the next epoch , and it only resets when all batches in the iterator have been processed, regardless of the end of an epoch? Thanks for the prompt response.
If you are using the most recent code, yes.
The issue may be that he doesn't know how to do this and is looking for an example for guidance, so asking him to contribute an example is counterproductive.
Thanks for the help!

I dont understand what exactly you are trying to do.
but using a output node as input to bias should work if the shape matches.

My PR is proof-of-concept of `lr_scheduler`. It works, but not perfect. There is one parameter I am still digging into, i.e. `epoch_size`. In mxnet _image-classification_ example (see [context](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/f91b2e51725aef700d619d8a605bbd6f437910bb/example/image-classification/train_model.py#L54)) , python implementation has supported specific `epoch_size` parameter (See [context](https://github.com/Gelu74/mxnet/blob/1bcdd6589046f4be4ce45e134ac0619092928abe/python/mxnet/model.py#L118-L120)) while my PR did not.

You're most likely right, but it still it could be a valid point to have some autoenconder example (apart from the mnist python, which could be good starting point, although probably too much bound to that concrete example). In general it is good to have a working example for most common use cases, as for many users this is a starting point to evaluate the toolkit. This is a good strategy for gaining the userbase (and other deep learning toolkits are doing it already).
It's probably easier to multiply the gradient matrix by a gate matrix and set the entries you want to update to 1 and others to 0
I completely agree with having a plethora of examples for users. I'm just commenting that people asking for examples aren't always the best people to create them.

Let me ask that way then.
I have a vector, with the shape of (A,1), resulting from a one-hidden-unit FullyConnected layer. For each of the A values, I want to repeat that value, such that now a (A,B,C,D) shape is obtained, where when we fix the first dimension, say i, the other three dimensions have the same i.th value of the vector, repeated in a (B,C,D) shaped tensor.

For example, lets assume I have the fully connected result, X, with the shape (500,1). In the 30. entry, lets say I have the value 95, X[29,0]=95. I want to transform this vector into a 4D tensor, say Y, of the shape (500,50,8,8), such that all entries will be Y[30,1,1,1]= ... = Y[30,49,7,7]=95.  And I want to do that using the symbolic operators in order to ensure correct forward and backward calculations. How can I do that?
reshape to (a, 1, 1, 1) then use deconvolution layer with weight initialized to 1 and fixed during training. Youll have to play with the kernel size a bit to get correct size
Actually no. You can use a fully connected layer to repeat and then do reshape.
Just remember to fix the weight and bias during training

The Google Inception v4 authors used RMSProp to train their best models. But it seems that training with RMSProp leads to no accuracy improvement. What parts of RMSProp are broken and when will them be fixed?

@piiswrong For some reason this solution is not working for me, even when I am using the latest commit of mxnet. The issue is as follows: epoch size is defined below

```
epoch_size = args.num_examples / args.batch_size
```

Yet, regardless of what I choose for num_examples, the epoch still only finishes when the data iterator makes a full pass through the data. For example, if I set num_examples = 32, and batch_size = 32, each batch should correspond to a single epoch correct? However, when calling fit, the model does not trigger epoch_callback until after the data iterator completes a full cycle. Is this a bug? or am I making a mistake somewhere? Thanks!

OK, you are right, if I do not use the lr_scheduler I get similar performance. I reference here your pull request for the records. 
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/1323
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/commit/19959849e8793b20c4642d290c798c27f516140c
Thanks!
@shuaitang  Have you fixed the problem? I've also find the exactly same problem and can not figure out the solution.
Just wanted to report that compiling the shared dll, with USE_CUDNN turned off worked. Thanks for your help.

I would like to be able to fine-tune with mxnet to keep things consistent, but the convert_model.py fails with errors already mentioned in #1419 

Are there any plans to update the conversion scripts? 

Regarding the flask server, I'll be happy to release that as soon as I'm convinced it's doing what I want.
If batch norm is followed by activations like ReLU, learning gamma is superfluous since bias can do the same thing.
It's working for me. You can go into model.py and see why it's not breaking at model.py:260L

I'm also seeing the same thing with MXNet.jl and on the LeNet example, even with the batch size turned all the way down.  (The 3-layer MLP example works fine, but cifar also won't run on a gpu).  Starting the training quickly uses up all the GPU memory.  If there's any more information I can provide to help on this please let me know.

![image](https://cloud.githubusercontent.com/assets/7132414/13617811/6d304aca-e535-11e5-94e6-b0faef8ad1ed.png)

Edit: Looks like this is already being worked on -- see the discussion starting in #1176 and #1176.

I have added a fix for this issue in the respective "feature/convolution-dilate" branches of my forks of mshadow and mxnet at

https://github.com/kadeng/mshadow/tree/feature/convolution-dilate
https://github.com/kadeng/mxnet/tree/feature/convolution-dilate

I made sure by looking at Impulse Responses of the Convolution op, that it's actually doing the right thing.

The change cuts across both projects, so I cannot put this in a single pull request. The changes come with a unittest, and I manually made sure (by looking at Impulse Responses of the operator) that it's actually working as intended.

Please review, and incorporate the changes into the main codebase as you see fit.
This pull request is probably ready to merge. Can somebody review this ? :) Thanks
LGTM
ive fix my MAE metric code long time, i thought its mine problem...
I created the first PR in mshadow. It passes all automated checks by now..
Steps to directly fine tune an MXNet model: https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/479#issuecomment-153809302.
https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/optimizer.py

The updater currently is unaware of layer-wise configuration.

```
def get_updater(optimizer):
    """Return a clossure of the updater needed for kvstore
    Parameters
    ----------
    optimizer: Optimizer
         The optimizer
    Returns
    -------
    updater: function
         The clossure of the updater
    """
    states = dict()
    def updater(index, grad, weight):
        """updater for kvstore"""
        if index not in states:
            states[index] = optimizer.create_state(index, weight)
        optimizer.update(index, weight, grad, states[index])
    return updater
```
This is one of the most common use cases. Have not anyone done this before with MXNet?
Would you please restart the effort of https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/issues/830 to make common tasks very easy to finish?
Would like to see a detailed hands-on tutorial too:

Yes, the actual fine-tuning is trivial and I've successfully done that on several pre-trained mxnet models. The current issue is just that the conversion scripts for caffe models are not up-to-date. So, using the caffe models as suggest by @xgastaldi isn't possible at the moment using the caffe model converter in its current state. I'll have some time to look into this during the weekend. If I figure out how to fix the scripts to recognize the BatchNorm layer appropriately, I'll open a PR.
LGTM

In Kaiming He's implementation, it seems they have a parameter called "use_global_stats". Do we have such a thing? It means we dont calculate the mean from the batch but use the global fixed one instead. @tqchen
I use the solver and fileIter of  the fcn-xs example, I only try a new network and initiate the parameters mannually

So there is no error in using CPU?

I think last time I saw `driver shutting down`, it is because memory is not enough.

Try linking the path where libcuda.so is located. So it would be -L/pathtolibcuda.so in the config.mk file
Also make sure put the location of your cuda library in USE_CUDA_PATH

@thirdwing Yes, there is no error using CPU. I think maybe this problem "Was due to cuda driver shutting down and some functions are called after the driver shutting down.", like in #1401. But I didn't figure out how to fix it.

I don't think so. At least in [model.R](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/R-package/R/model.R), those `cat` calls are not conditioned on verbosity. 

Best,
Yuan

Now I compiled it successfully, I also compiled the python package. But when I tried to import mxnet, I got this error:

```
>>> import mxnet
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File "<stdin>", line 1, in <module>
  File "mxnet/__init__.py", line 7, in <module>
    from .base import MXNetError
  File "mxnet/base.py", line 43, in <module>
    _LIB = _load_lib()
  File "mxnet/base.py", line 35, in _load_lib
    lib = ctypes.cdll.LoadLibrary(lib_path[0])
  File "/apps/software/Python/2.7.11-foss-2015b/lib/python2.7/ctypes/__init__.py", line 443, in LoadLibrary
    return self._dlltype(name)
  File "/apps/software/Python/2.7.11-foss-2015b/lib/python2.7/ctypes/__init__.py", line 365, in __init__
    self._handle = _dlopen(self._name, mode)
OSError: /home/a1689670/mxnet/python/mxnet/../../lib/libmxnet.so: undefined symbol: cudnnBatchNormalizationForwardInference
```

The all previous steps were all successful except for this.

I finally figured out what wasn't working. I am using train_model.py from the image_classifications examples directory in my pipeline, but calling mx.FeedForward with the model_args keyword argument does not initialize epoch_size correctly for some odd reason. I added in the epoch_size parameter to the FeedForward function manually, and the model worked correctly. Is this issue working on your end?
Problem solved. Basically, it's my lack of understanding of NN structure. For regression, the output layer always needs  num_hidden=1.

Hi [executor_manager.py:L127](https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/python/mxnet/executor_manager.py#L127) is trying to bind a new executor and share parameter with existing executor. The error occurs because the size of the existing parameter is different parameter. Note we have an assumption that in bucketing, the parameter for models in different bucket are the same (and shared). Can you please
- Verify if this assumption is true for your scenario? 
- Check either your data iter is reporting the correct shapes in `provide_data`? Note both the data iter and the batch need to report correct `provide_data` if bucketing is used.
- You can insert some print statement at executor_manager.py:L127 right before the assert to print the `name`, and `arg_arr.shape`, `arg_shape[i]`, which might be able to help to find out what is wrong.
You should need cuda. Make sure use_cuda is turned off.

I did add the cuda path, it was correct. Then I got the error as I showed above. You said make sure use_cuda is turned off. Do you mean in "mxnet_predict0.cc"? I did not change it, and it is like:

```
#define MSHADOW_FORCE_STREAM

```

Thanks. I'll be quite busy on the following couple of days so was thinking to merge it first. Thanks for double checking and help!

Since I suspected it could because of the version of CUDA, I tried another one CUDA 7.0 (The previous one was CUDA 7.5). Now I got another problem, 

```
No such file or directory #include <cuda_fp16.h>
```

After looking it through, it seems this file is only in CUDA7.5. It is so confusing. Do I have to use CUDA 7.5 strictly? Since this Amalgamation is like a platform independent framework and it's only dependency is OpenBlas, why would we need the other things like cuda. According to the README, after assigning the openblas path, the only thing is make. So anything I have missed? @tqchen @piiswrong

Working on a paper for WABI conference.

@javelinjs The mshadow I use is "mshadow @ 1286bea". I find that "dmlc/mshadow:master" is 2 commits ahead of the mshadow used in mxnet. Maybe mxnet needs to update this submodule. Thanks!

I dump the data before executor_manager.py:L127.
name : decoder_l0_i2h_weight
arg_arr.shape : (32L,)
arg_shape[i]    : (512L, 128L)

It is really weird, since i2h weight is not in the input provide data. Only the input provide data has the shape (batch_size, ), in which batch_size = 32.

I will follow other suggestion you mentioned and give you feedback if i can find something.

Now I know how to save the Ndarray,but still don't know how to save a trained model.

@kelly-lxg Good question. It needs some hack efforts to make mxnet run in one spark stage. If you have any idea, feel free to let us know. @CodingCat and @tqchen are doing similar things with xgboost4j, they have experiences on this.
@ziyeqinghan yeah, commit 6a9d036 fixed a potential uncaught error. Please let me know if it works, thank you.
We may don't agree the spark interface plan which sparknet take, because it may allocate memory twice both in c++ and jvm.  Do you have some feasible way? thanks!
@javelinjs It solves the problem. Thank you so much :)

When continue learning pre-trained inception-bn model from model gallery on whole imagenet 1000 class training data (prepared own .rec-file using im2rec, manually checked for correct labeling) I would expect (training) accuracy at around what is cited on https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet-model-gallery/blob/master/imagenet-1k-inception-bn.md

However when I do the following, I was surprised to find learning to start from scratch (i.e. at training accuracy 0.001): 
python example/image-classification/train-imagenet.py --load-epoch=39 --model-prefix=PATH_TO_PRETRAINED_MODEL/Inception_BN --data-dir=PATH_TO_IMAGENET_ITERATORS --train-dataset=imagenet_train.rec --val-dataset=imagenet_val.rec

It seems that the pre-trained model is somehow re-initialized with random weights / not appropriately loaded from Inception_BN-0039.params. Can train-imagenet.py not be used to continue training pre-trained model from model gallery?

I checked data iter and batch report same provide_data.

It seems the order in arg_names = sym.list_arguments() is not sorted 
in executor_manager.py:L99 

I dumped arg_names from two buckets, 
the first bucket (encoder_len = 5, decoder_len = 5) initialized the arg_arrays according to the first arg_names from executor_manager.py:L99

after the first bucket initialized, it bind to the base_executor in the order of first arg_names.

However,  arg_names in the second bucket (encoder_len = 10, decoder_len  = 10) does not have the exactly same order with the first bucket. Since some parameter had bind to the base_executor, it goes to second branch in executor_manager.py:L118, in which case it does not check shared_data_arrays, but refer to base_exec.arg_arrays to retrieve the arg_arr. And in my case, two different parameter (encoder_data/5, decoder_l0_i2h_weight) happened to occupy the same slot in base_exec.arg_arrays, thus triggering the shape incompatible error. 

What I find weird is, when I go back to the original example using lstm for ptb language modeling. 
It does not have any trouble in name-arrays alignment.

Does this have anything to do with my bucket setup. Since in seq2seq model, each bucket is a tuple of (encoder_len, decoder_len), while in ptb language model, bucket only contain seq_len?

Looking forwards to your suggestion and help.
Thank you.
I've got your idea and  I will try,Thanks.
@0rchard Thanks for the information. I believe this is a bug! Let me look into it!

Is this due to the Nones in grad arrays?
Why is the order different?

Does this affect executor.reshape?

@piiswrong I think this does not affect `executor.reshape`, as reshape use the same symbol. But for bucketing, different symbols are used, and the ordering of parameters might not be very predictable.

Could you change the folder name cnn to something more informative?
like cnn_text_classification?
Otherwise LGTM

Also please add a entry in https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/example/README.md
OK. LGTM, lets merge this
@0rchard We have just merged a patch that should have fixed the problem. Can you test if it is working now?
@mli

Use https://github.com/dmlc/mxnet/blob/master/src/ndarray/ndarray.cc#L573
And save it like 

```
save_dict = {('arg:%s' % k) : v for k, v in arg_params.items()}
save_dict.update({('aux:%s' % k) : v for k, v in aux_params.items()})
param_name = '%s-%04d.params' % (prefix, epoch)
nd.save(param_name, save_dict)
```

as in model.py:save_checkpoint
+1 for this PR. Hoping it can be added soon as an easy way to monitor and log multiple metrics.

Thanks for the PR. I have made two comments:
- Use enumerate to enumerate over index and item if you need index. other wise, use 
  `for metric in eval_metric`
- Always assume the eval_metric is a list, in the beginning of train function, do  conversion if it is not
@thirdwing what is the status on this PR?
@lyttonhao Do we have any updates on this? Thanks!
ok, I will update it, thanks

This is what I am thinking about. When fine tuning a model, If the batch is so small during training, the batch mean and variance may not be sufficient enough. It might be better to just use global variance instead of calculating the batch mean and variance each time. What do you think? @tqchen @piiswrong
@tqchen Sorry about the delay. I will update it soon after a conference deadline.
Great
I see what you mean, this could be an possible option added to the BatchNorm, you are welcomed to open an PR
